description.text: A view towards the mountains near Chakrota, India. The peak of the mountain is snow-capped while the rest of it is black.

inscription.text: A view of Snow, Chakrota Hill (India).

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

titleSet.title: A view of snow, Chakrota Hill (India)

ext:item.ext:value: text-en: A view of Snow, Chakrota Hill (India).
description-en: A view towards the mountains near Chakrota, India. The peak of the mountain is snow-capped while the rest of it is black. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: In this image, the viewer is suspended in space somewhere far away from the foreground, with no anchoring feature in the foreground to firmly situate the viewer's vantage point. It is a precarious position. Also, while we are looking at a point far away, the sheer size of the mountain makes it impossible for us to look down on it. The eternal snow on those peaks are untamable through mere sight. These visual details conjure up a sense of a terrain not easy to access or possess. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The earliest encounters of Europeans with the Himalayas provoked in them a particular mixture of anxiety, awe and fear in the face of a wild and overpowering “grandeur” that they referred to as “the sublime.” This was a reaction familiar to Europeans from their encounter with the Alps. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

related literature: Kenny, Judith 1995. "Climate, Race, and Imperial Authority: The Symbolic Landscape of the British Hill Station in India." In Annals of the Association of American Geographers 85, no. 4 (1995): 694-714. (gs)
related literature: Mathur S. 2007. "India by Design: Colonial History and Cultural Display". Berkeley, Los Angeles, London: University of California Press; pp. 230. (gs)
related literature: Mitchell, W. J. T. 2002 "Imperial Landscape." In Landscape and Power, W. J. T Mitchell, 5-34. Chicago and London: The University of Chicago Press. (gs)

related literature: Talukdar, Shashwati 2010. "Picturing Mountains As Hills. Hill Station Postcards and the Tales They Tell" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/102/index.html, last accessed 2010-12-15. (gs)

Kenny, Judith 1995. "Climate, Race, and Imperial Authority: The Symbolic Landscape of the British Hill Station in India." In Annals of the Association of American Geographers 85, no. 4 (1995): 694-714.
Mitchell, W. J. T. 2002 "Imperial Landscape." In Landscape and Power, W. J. T Mitchell, 5-34. Chicago and London: The University of Chicago Press.
Talukdar, Shashwati 2010. "Picturing Mountains As Hills. Hill Station Postcards and the Tales They Tell" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/102/index.html, last accessed 2010-12-15.
Mathur S. 2007. "India by Design: Colonial History and Cultural Display". Berkeley, Los Angeles, London: University of California Press; pp. 230.

The earliest encounters of Europeans with the Himalayas provoked in them a particular mixture of anxiety, awe and fear in the face of a wild and overpowering “grandeur” that they referred to as “the sublime.” This was a reaction familiar to Europeans from their encounter with the Alps.

In this image, the viewer is suspended in space somewhere far away from the foreground, with no anchoring feature in the foreground to firmly situate the viewer's vantage point. It is a precarious position. Also, while we are looking at a point far away, the sheer size of the mountain makes it impossible for us to look down on it. The eternal snow on those peaks are untamable through mere sight. These visual details conjure up a sense of a terrain not easy to access or possess.
